required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: User Acceptability of a Device-Based Opioid Overdose Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: A Proof of Concept, Randomized, Single Center Study on Frameworks for Wearable Devices to Sense and Respond to Opioid Overdoses

brief_summary.textblock: This pilot study evaluates the needs of opioid users for a device-based intervention for opioid overdoses. The results of this one-time short questionnaire will inform development of a novel naloxone delivery device.

detailed_description.textblock: All opioid overdose related deaths can be prevented with the timely delivery of Naloxone. This study is a one-time, preliminary survey of participants with opioid use disorder to assess the need for, and community attitudes towards, a wearable device capable of autonomously detecting and responding to an opioid overdose. The results of this survey will be used to guide ongoing development of a de novo device. This study will be conducted over a 3 month period and survey participants from the Kensington Neighborhood in North Philadelphia.

primary_outcome.measure: Community Need for a Device-based Opioid Overdose Intervention
primary_outcome.description: We aim to characterize the degree of need for a device-based opioid overdose intervention. These were extracted from the participant survey questions as well as from the words, phrases, and sentences used by participants during the interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Functional and Aesthetic Preferences for Device-based Opioid Overdose Intervention
secondary_outcome.description: We aim to characterize the functional and aesthetic preferences of the participant population for a device-based opioid overdose intervention. These were extracted from the participant survey questions as well as from the words, phrases, and sentences used by participants during the interview.

arm_group.description: This group of participants will complete a survey about their opioid use history and their preferences for a device-based intervention. They will then participate in a semi-structured interview to provide feedback on non-functional, "looks-like" prototypes of such a device.

intervention.description: Participants will complete a survey about their opioid use history, its impact on their lives, their current strategies for preventing or reversing opioid overdoses, and their preferences for a device-based intervention.
Participants will participate in a semi-structured interview, during which they will provide feedback on non-functional, "looks-like" prototypes of a naloxone delivery device.

study_pop.textblock: Study population is non-pregnant individuals over the age of 21 with opioid use disorder.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Have used opioids for more than 3 months or will be having surgery where opioids will be administered
- Able to provide informed consent
- Moderate to severe chronic pain treated with opioids or recreational use
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Patient Participants
group.description: This group of participants will complete a survey about their opioid use history and their preferences for a device-based intervention. They will then participate in a semi-structured interview to provide feedback on non-functional, "looks-like" prototypes of such a device. Survey: Participants will complete a survey about their opioid use history, its impact on their lives, their current strategies for preventing or reversing opioid overdoses, and their preferences for a device-based intervention. Interview: Participants will participate in a semi-structured interview, during which they will provide feedback on non-functional, "looks-like" prototypes of a naloxone delivery device.

class.title: Likely to use a device that senses an overdose
Likely to use a device that indicates the wearer is at risk of an overdose
Likely to use a device that straps naloxone to the body for a bystander to administer
Likely to use a device that senses an overdose and administers naloxone if needed
Likely to use a device that alerts medical first responders if needed
Likely to use a device that alerts bystanders if needed
Likely to use a device that monitors vital signs
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a necklace
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a canula
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a skin-patch on chest
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a skin-patch on upper arm
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a watch-appearing bracelet
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a wrist bracelet
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a shoulder strap
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a thigh strap
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a chest strap
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear glasses
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear a knee brace
For a device that sense overdose - likely to wear an ankle strap

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data was collected at the time of survey administration (1 hour).
reported_events.desc: Participants were asked to complete a survey and participate in an interview. There is no risk for mortality or serious adverse events from these activities.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
